reviewText:
The game is fast first person platformer. A fresh new adaptation of true and tried platforming. Rather than moving slowly and timing the jump from the edge. Speed is what counts here. You need to be moving at a constant speed to kick open doors, catch a drop wire etc. etc. Every thing is setup for constant nonstop movement. The level designs are so perfect; once you get hang of controls there is no need to stop. The game takes you through roof tops, A/C vents, malls, office walk ways and lots of other varied setups. At every stage there are multiple paths to move forward. There is a lot of freedom and it is tied well with risks.

A critical thing to understand here is that the start-up period of the game is ROUGH. You are expected to be able to wall-jump, balance on thin rails, jump over chasms, and do other challenging things. The controls are going to be hard to get used to. Don't give up. It could be frustrating. Stick at it, and give yourself time to get used to those controls. Keep working through the initial levels. The reward is well worth it.

Once you become used to the controls, the game really becomes captivating. You're expected to race top speed through a variety of obstacle courses. You have to think on the fly, react instantly, and pay attention to clues. It draws your mind in to focus on the moment.

You can replay levels to try different paths, to try to get a better speed, and simply to have fun. So even if you solve" a level in one way
date: there are reasons to go back and replay them multiple times.\n\nThis game has been agony and ecstasy for me
recommended: and when I beat it I felt exhilarated. If you are a high-energy gamer who has the patience to try and try again

reviewText:
Mirrors Edge
The Great Game That Nobody Bought

Before I start, ignore how long I have played this game. I mainly played this offline.

Mirrors Edge is a first person parkour game with some shooting elements. All combined highlights Faith's (the main character) trip through this beautiful city. The small details in the graphics, such as motion blur and even the dust particles when you land after a massive jump make this experience feel real at times. Highly recommended for fans of parkour based gameplay with the occasional fast paced, reflex combat.

Also this is one of the very few first person games where you can acually see your feet as well as your arms.  Mirrors Edge is also a fantastic game because it still looks good even if you don't have a gaming PC to run it. Futhermore it doesn't take up that much space on your computer. (around 7 gigs or so)

The only downside to this game is that it is a bit too short (around 6 hours). Keep in mind this is pretty much the only downside to this game.

Verdict
9/10

reviewText:
The epitome of artistic game design. The combination of visuals, graphics, artistic feel and look of the game is just astonishing. The first game to do parkour and freerunning any real justice, ME shows you what it's like to be that guy/or girl without having to leave your damn seat.  DICE really nailed it but while as an idea it seems to work great, in practice a parkour game would be quite lacking in terms of content. And that is the main issue with the game: not enough content. Yes, there are speedruns to keep you playing and compete against other players worldwide but that does not really add any realistic level of playtime to the game. Most people won‚Äôt even bother.

If DICE had more time to tinker with the game, other notable examples to get ideas from (absolutely none at the time) or maybe more resources to work with, we could have possibly seen a much bigger game with a larger player base (that‚Äôs not to say that it was an experimental game, not at all). That perhaps explains why ME was not a major financial success, but still the most loved underrated game of all time.

Everyone wanted a sequel, even those that logged like no more than 10 minutes into the game thought it‚Äôs cool and deserves a sequel. We are getting the sequel and it looks very promising so far. In my opinion, all that DICE needs to do to make sure that ME2 is a huge financial success is add more content, keep the feel and look of the game and improve it further.

DICE‚Äôs work has always been inspiring and Mirror‚Äôs Edge is no different. The addition of combat and the constant feeling of  ‚ÄúI have to keep running to evade the highly trained ninja monkey special forces that are after me for no apparent reason (IHKREHTNMSFAMNAR)‚Äú adds a sense of danger and foreboding to the game. It‚Äôs parkour as it should be.

Parkour is cool and everyone knows it. If you haven‚Äôt yet played the game, you owe it to yourself to do so.

Just don‚Äôt go and play it with the Oculus Rift, especially not if you‚Äôre afraid of heights.

You have been warned‚Ä¶.

reviewText: Beautiful work of art, cleanly inspiring us for the better. Now I do wish to say more about this game, I played it years ago on my neighbors xbox 360 but now I am looking forward to Catalyst! It reminds me of hitman which is funny. So the point I wish to bring up now is about the settings, I have a GTX 980 Ti (Very high graphics card) But I had problems running this game, at certain points. This is entirely because of PhysX. There are two files which are in the game when you install here on Steam, and if you remove them then the problem is fixed, because this game came out half a decade ago, those files are outdated, and removing them will allow proper updated ones that you already should have to take their place, the files you need to find are called: PhysXCore.dll & PhysXDevice.dll. To find them go to Where Steam is on your computer, usually under program files x86, then steamapps, common, mirrors edge of course, then the first file maybe, called binaries, just find and delete those two I mentioned before hand and you should be completley done if you are up to date otherwise. Now this works as of now for me, maybe it will not in the future but I think it is worth doing this right now to try to help others. reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Mirror's Edge is a first person Parkour game developed by DICE in 2009. I don't know if this is ‚Äúthe first Parkour game ever developed‚Äù, but it is the first I've ever played, and I suspect it can earn its place as one of the first and one of the good ones.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You play as the Protagonist named ‚ÄúFaith‚Äù... I see what you did there DICE, touch√©. Faith is part of a rebel group that has risen up against the oppressive ruling government which monitors all communication within this city,  sound familiar? Hmmm...
Faith is a ‚Äúrunner‚Äù, runners are individuals who act as couriers that carries messages around the city. Runners see the world in a different way; where one person might see a dead end, a runner see's opportunities to climb, jump, and vault to get to their objective.

Gameplay: Mirror's Edge has one extremely strong selling point: First person Parkour. Have you ever wanted to jump off a building and not break your kneecaps? Have you ever wanted to travel a zip line from a skyscaper? Mirror's Edge is for you!
There are various types of obstacles that you'll face throughout the game, the game teaches you how to deal with each one by going through a ‚Äútraining‚Äù session before you start the game. This training is skip-able but I suggest you get through it... but I'll be honest, I probably spent more time on the training then the first level. I could not master the ‚Äúturn-around-wall-jump‚Äù, every time I missed the game would force-ably restart my attempt.

Achievements: At this time there are no steam achievements for Mirror's Edge, however on the Xbox there are 50 Achievements, so it's possible sometime in the future Mirror's Edge might have achievements, but at this time (08/03/15) there are no achievements.
There might not be achievements for Mirror's Edge, but there are time trials that you can complete against your friends on, unfortunately they're not sync-ed with steam leaderboards, so you would need to add your friends in game via Origin account.

Price: Mirror's Edge is priced at $19.99, I completed this game on Normal difficulty in 7 hours. I want my games to go an hour for every dollar spent... If you go by that standard you should wait for this game to go on sale.
However if you have the money, this is an excellent Parkour game that you definitely should give a try at some point, regardless of cost.

Conclusion: To recap... Story: Okay, Gameplay: Excellent + Parkour, Achievements: Not available at this time, Price: a bit high.
I recommend this game to anyone who likes jumping puzzles in first or third person video games. You can fight your way through the game (that's what I did) however it's not designed to cater to the fighting crowd (but it's so fun to punch out one guy, grab his gun and rata-tata-tata!), the game is designed to be like a Parkour or Free running simulator. And many times feels quite realistic on what you can and cannot survive... well almost, I did some pretty messed up stunts.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a unique and wonderful experience. There are some rough edges, but it's a beautiful and memorable game.

The closest gameplay comparison I can make is Portal. If you enjoyed the challenges in Portal 2, you will likely enjoy Mirror's Edge, too. The puzzles of both these games are about figuring out how to master a complex open 3D arena through trial and error, and the sense of fulfillment when you figure out the solutions in both games is similar.

Mirror's Edge is set in a beautiful near-future city, with abstract gleaming white towers and stunning vistas. Outside, you engage in parkour-style running, navigating high ledges and leaping from tower to tower, in a fluid manner. It‚Äôs similar to the more familiar Assassin's Creed games, but faster. Indoor sequences are more puzzley, usually about getting from Point A to Point B efficiently. The free running is exhilarating, both outdoors and indoors. Missing a jump by a faction of an inch and falling to your death will make your fingers tingle as you catch your breath! And there was a memorable close encounter with a subway train that made me jump out of my seat from the adrenaline surge.

Unfortunately, Mirror's Edge also features awkward combat sequences. The early training missions teach complicated combo moves for executing martial arts maneuvers. For example: blocking a punch while taking a weapon off an enemy. Honestly, these moves were way too complicated for me to execute confidently, but I quickly learned one easy combo that served me well in every situation: the slide-tackle. Turns out that if you take people out at the knees, everything else goes pretty smoothly!

These combat events are generally unwelcome in an otherwise excellent game. Disabling a cop as you round a corner, then dash away? That's fun. Disabling a cop, taking his weapon, and then having a shootout with his partners for 5 minutes, moving from cover to cover? This does not match the overall theme of the game, and it's a distraction. Fortunately, these combat events are few and far between, and not difficult enough to frustrate you, or dissuade you from completing the game. Think of them as a different kind of puzzle.

Last word: The trailer that Steam offers in the Store page is a poor choice. It features the cartoony animation from some of the between-levels cutscenes.  The actual gameplay is more like this trailer:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2N1TJP1cxmo

Definitely consider Mirror's Edge; it's fine entertainment.

reviewText:
Mirror‚Äôs Edge consistently feels like the point of impact for two diverging strains of game design.

There is, first, the game Mirror‚Äôs Edge would propose itself to be, a first-person parkour escapade through a city overrun by corporate interest. It‚Äôs a crunchy, mechanics focused affair sold on the adrenaline rush that is leaping off a rooftop and hitting the ground in an effortlessly smooth, lifesaving roll. Where games such as Assassin‚Äôs Creed and Prince of Persia employ parkour as a flashy means to a navigational end, Mirror‚Äôs Edge obsesses over the act of putting one foot in front of the other; a roll here, a leap there, each action a purposeful and considered exertion meant to carry you forward as fast as possible with as little surface friction as can be managed.

The precision Mirror‚Äôs Edge demands of you in controlling your character‚Äôs body is at once overwhelming and exhilarating. I routinely felt as if the game demanded more of me than its simple over/under controls allowed for, but then I would flawlessly string together a series of moves and everything would snap into place. There is a delicate balance struck between contextual automation and player driven navigation in how you traverse the industrial playgrounds that make up Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs levels, and more often than not the choice to keep the actual controls simple pays off and helps make for a game that feels both smooth and tactile.

Problems arise though when Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs level designs fail to match the intuitive nature of its controls. There is a distinct visual vocabulary at work in Mirror‚Äôs Edge that seeks to clue you in on what can and can‚Äôt be climbed, jumped, and run on, familiar objects and situations giving way to habitual movements that streamline the planning phase and keep you moving. But despite what attempts Mirror‚Äôs Edge makes to help teach you how to read levels, by and large they remain entirely opaque. I might recognize a piece of geometry, but rarely did that translate into me knowing how to actually use it to move forward, and again and again I would find myself having to slow down and deconstruct a level before I could move forward.

This stop-and-go workaround is certainly functional, but it goes entirely against the way Mirror‚Äôs Edge seems designed to be, and how it wants you to play. For a game built with speed and flow as top priorities, Mirror‚Äôs Edge does a poor job ensuring you ever make it through a level without needing to first memorize its layout and the sequence of moves needed to successfully navigate it. It‚Äôs not impossible to get good at Mirror‚Äôs Edge and capitalize on its promises, but doing so requires such an investment of time and energy spent beating yourself against its inscrutable exterior, that it hardly feels worth it. I never expected to reach speedrun level proficiency without putting in the effort, but Mirror‚Äôs Edge fails to accommodate for players who fall anywhere outside the hyper dedicated and skilled, without feeling as if that exclusion is an intentional choice. I don‚Äôt believe developer DICE wanted Mirror‚Äôs Edge to be as hard and frustrating as it ultimately became, but perhaps that is just what happens to games that move as fast and are as demanding as this.

But I feel as if most of Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs failings are less the result of design oversights than they are the splintering of priorities. I said earlier that Mirror‚Äôs Edge feels like two strains of game design, and that second side comes into play in all the ways Mirror‚Äôs Edge either fails to flesh out the parts one would believe to be most important, or the things it chooses to include for no discernible reason. The much maligned combat is likely the biggest offender in this regard. You are rarely forced to engage with enemies, but not doing can often make the game more challenging than it is worth. Often I ran into situations where I would die dozens of times without making it through, only to reluctantly pick up a gun and be out in a matter of moments.

The reason combat is so annoying then is the same reason much of the game becomes a frustrating slog the further you progress: it keeps slowing you down. There is also the added fact that combat, while technically functional, is horrifically clunky and unsatisfying, with kicks and punches being by far the least controlled actions you perform in the game, and the gunplay feeling loose and awkward (which is especially strange given DICE‚Äôs shooter roots). It all feels like a last second inclusion, as if someone high up at EA saw the game running and became worried that no one would buy a game without combat. One can only speculate as to the various hierarchies at play in Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs development, but that doesn‚Äôt change how wholly alien the combat feels to the rest of the game, and its inclusion means that at some point development time was being allocated to it over the rest of the game (the end result being the game we received).

That isn‚Äôt to say that if DICE had opted-out of combat they would have been able to fix all of Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs problems, but when so much of the game feels rushed it seems hard to imagine that time couldn‚Äôt have been better spent elsewhere. The campaign itself is brief even by shooter standards at anywhere from 4-6 hours, and is made to feel more insubstantial due to being married to a narrative that is structurally akin to a show billed for 24 episodes that got cut down to 12. There is a framework here setting up a fascinating near future, where the control of information is paramount, and the only way to get messages relayed outside the government‚Äôs prying eyes is to use runners who carry them by hand. Our lead, Faith, is a quintessential sentimental rebel, enacting what eventually becomes an outright war between the city higher-ups and the runners in order to rescue her sister after being framed for a crime.

There is a lot to work with in Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs setting and premise, but events are strung together with so little continuity and character development that the result is something of a mess. Much of Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs plot seems to hint at a history that is never explained, with character relationships never getting much attention even as they switch sides at the drop of a hat without any legitimate justification. Eventually things boil down to a blur of small-scale politics with big ramifications, plot holes that make for easy conclusions, and an overarching storyline that by the end seems to have gone nowhere despite everything that unfolds. I am a sucker for Marxist dystopia and would have loved to learn more about Faith‚Äôs world and how she fits into it. It is incredibly rare we get a female lead in games, which makes it perhaps more frustrating than it would otherwise be that Mirror‚Äôs Edge does nothing much to develop Faith as a person. I appreciate her being here and DICE avoiding most of the pitfalls that developers fall into in creating female characters, but that only serves to illustrate just how dire things are in games even so many years after Mirror‚Äôs Edge‚Äôs release, that even being a lousy character in her own right Faith still constitutes one of the better leading ladies in a major release.

Mirror‚Äôs Edge is an experience that few games have come anywhere near replicating. Its blend of high-contrast visuals and a visceral sense of movement and impact can be incredibly exhilarating once you learn how to make use of what you‚Äôre given. However compelling a concept Mirror‚Äôs Edge might be though, its execution is so flawed as to make playing it often far less enjoyable than the idea of doing so. With a sequel on the horizon it will be interesting to see if DICE learned anything from Mirror‚Äôs Edge relative failure, but until then it exists more as a curiosity than a classic.

reviewText:
I finally decided to play this. What a rush! This is the sort of game that can be played ten years from now and it will still play great and look great. It's one of those timeless games.

Positives:
Simple and refined gameplay, check. The free running is so very enjoyable. The sense of speed as you rush across rooftops is exhilirating. For someone like me who loves the thrill of heights, it puts a grin on my face. (You'll probably want to raise the game's FOV, it's pretty easy, look it up.)
I want to live in that city. Maybe without the dystopia but, it looks so nice. The art direction in the game is gorgeous. Indoors also. I want to work in those offices. I would desk jockey the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of those office environments.
You can take a screenshot at any time and hang it on your wall. My F12 key is wearing out.
I liked the world they created. The runner culture. The story keeps it simple, with just enough to provide you with incentive. Character designs are great too, from Faith to the runners and villains. Check out the unlockable art in the main menu.
I was sad to hear Rhianna Pratchett wasn't invited to write Mirror's Edge 2 because  I liked her take on this. A girl on the wrong side of the law who's doing everything to save her her sister, the framed cop. Interesting backstory to the city and the characters. I'd love an animated series with the same setting and aesthetics.

The negatives:
Combat is definitely the weak point of the game. Most of the time it's frustrating. Lots of people wish it didn't have combat at all. I think they could have made it work. You can disarm most enemies via quicktime events that suck, even if you use the slowmo button.
For a game about free running, it's pretty damn linear. I've seen corridor shooters that offered more varied paths. At least I played it without runner vision" which literally paints your path in red.
I didn't mind these but it seems a lot of people did: the cutscene cartoons are not as well made as the rest of the game. Not a big deal for me.
Mirror's Edge 2 is supposed to address these issues

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge was developed by DICE and released in 2010. Unlike other DICE games, Mirror's Edge wasn't using the Frostbite engine, instead they went with Unreal Engine 3.

There is no game like it. The parkour is simply amazing here. There is no run button in this game - instead your character simply builds up speed as she runs. To complete an obstacle, you have to do it all in an instant, without stopping. It's not really about planning or puzzles, but more about instinct. You really have to give it to the level design in this game. Without right level design none of it would really feel right. All of that really make it feel very natural and epic. DICE really managed to combine cinematic feel (and i don't mean 30 fps) and gameplay together. I wouldn't mind for a open world though.

There is also a bit of FPS in this game. You can never hold on to a gun or reload it. You have  to attack the enemy to get the gun, but it's easier said than done though. The game wants you to be tactical, even if you attack an enemy that only had a pistol, he will still gun you down if you just run out in the open to him like that. You have to use cover, pick the ones that are separated from the rest etc.

The gameplay component of the game, whether it's parkour or shootouts, is simply amazing.

The game also has nice use of aesthetics. They use primary colors mixed with white for the most part. It's so simplistic, yet so gorgeous. Musical department wasn't lacking either. Main theme by Lisa Miskovsky is superb.

Unfortunately this game suffers from one big problem - the length. It will take you about 4 hrs to complete it. I guess EA thought of it as an experiment project?

Additionally, there are also those terrible cutscenes in between the levels. Clearly shows the limited budget EA has given.

Usually i dismiss these 4 hrs long games. Most of them offer no originality and are overpriced. But due to unique nature of Mirror's Edge i will have to recommend it. There is really no game like it.

reviewText:
I can not express the love I have for this game with words. Though one thing needs to be said: the game IS flawed.

The universe and art direction is breathtaking, it takes risks, it's gorgeous... but they didn't really expand on the backstory enough. The gameplay is awesome: you run from rooftop to rooftop, you climb stuff, you make dangerous jumps while the police chases you, etc. but sometimes the flow of the game is completely broken by mandatory gunfights (which are thankfully few and far between).

That said, Mirror's Edge is everything good that can come out of a big studio & publisher. I'm repeating myself, but the design of the city is just THAT good. The character design is pretty good; and hey! For once, we finally have an AAA game where a woman is the lead character! And last but not least, the sound design & soundtrack is the cherry on top of the cake: psychic ambient & downtempo electronica by Solar Fields, in a style that mixes two of his best albums: Leaving Home (2005) and EarthShine (2007).

One of my favorite games ever, and I'm eagerly waiting for the sequel...

reviewText:
Mirror‚Äôs Edge is a game in its own league because there aren‚Äôt many ‚Äì if any ‚Äì like it. The gameplay consists of running, jumping, sliding, kicking, etc. You‚Äôre in (almost) constant motion. The learning curve is steep and you‚Äôre required to have a lot of patience. You might not even get full enjoyment out of it if you‚Äôve just played through the game once, unless you get the hang of it straight away. Now, at first I thought that the game‚Äôs just unfair and unnecessarily difficult... until I stopped making things too complicated for myself.  Unfortunately, that happened about an hour and a half before the end of the main campaign. I expected all the routes to be very linear and complicated but the truth is that there are many ways to get from one place to another. I just had to open my eyes, learn how to notice things and think simply.

Pros:
‚Ä¢	The game is at its best during chase sequences and, fortunately, there‚Äôs a lot of them. You can actually feel the thrill of being chased while you‚Äôre running away from enemies.
‚Ä¢	The graphics are gorgeous and the visual style is quite fascinating. I saw some wonderful greens, oranges and blues. A real sight for sore eyes.
‚Ä¢	You can run through timed race tracks that are fun to complete. A good way to hone your skills.
‚Ä¢	Running feels very smooth once you get a hang of the controls.
‚Ä¢	There are some really exciting moments, like running towards a fast approaching train.
‚Ä¢	The soundtrack is really cool and fits the world and atmosphere perfectly.
‚Ä¢	Standing on the edge of tall buildings gives vertigo.

Cons:
‚Ä¢	Early on in the game the routes might seem confusing or not obvious. Often it‚Äôs not clear where you‚Äôre supposed to go, the indicators are misleading and so on. What I learned is that the routes that make you think, There‚Äôs no way in hell I‚Äôm supposed to go that way"
date: turn out to be the right ones.\n‚Ä¢	The game‚Äôs very bright
recommended:
so it may be straining on people with sensitive eyes. The brightness can always be turned down but I found that this makes the game lose some of its visual appeal.
‚Ä¢	Reloading autosaves may place you slightly ahead of where you just were and that might create some confusion.
‚Ä¢	The main campaign is short. I believe it can be completed in under 5-6 hours.

reviewText:
This review is written from the perspective of someone who likes the game a lot, beware of bias and take it with a grain of salt.
TL:DR - It‚Äôs twenty dollars, so damn cheap for what you get. Unless you are broke, BUY IT.

Full Review:

Let's start out with what I expected after watching the trailers and pictures:
Parkour
Pretty maps
Hand to hand and combat
I got my parkour, pretty maps, and hand to hand combat. I also got a short story and very simple but annoying and unforgiving controls.

Oh the controls... Given that one of the very important parts of this game is parkour, you would think it would be the most fleshed out and well done part of the game right? Wrong, unless you are on point with your movement every time, the game will punish you with the same old falling animation. Fighting or running away from enemies is a whole other deal. The game has a very simple movement base which can be fun when you fight enemies. Sometimes enemies get weird advantages and knock you down/do a lot of damage that nearly kills you; Some enemies are not meant to be fought so when you do fight them, you know why they are able to nearly instantly kill you. Even though one of the core elements of the game was designed poorly it won‚Äôt dock it points for this. Mirror's Edge came out in 2008 and I am willing to bet that not much was done to study how good its combat/movement system was since back then not many games could be used to compare it and see what it lacked/boasted.

The art and modeling is so good. Without a doubt in my mind this game has absolutely beautiful looking maps, just visually at least, and even better looking models for props in the game. The maps however don‚Äôt feel like they were meant to be used for parkour. With all the clutter everywhere(yes clutter, even though it looks very clean), it is hard to really enjoy the game. I think the mappers did a lazy job of planning the maps which ended up making most maps feel slow, unintuitive, and clunky. A little bit more effort in the development of player movement through the maps would have gone a long way. On Top of all this the maps are relatively small making it very apparent they are linear. But like I said in my previous paragraph this game was made without much to go off of so this feels more like it was an experiment that went pretty well rather than a real game franchise.

The sounds/music are just ounces of amazing. This game had extremely good and worked out tracks for different times during each map. The attention in detail to the sound as well as the physical location of the player made this special and memorable. I really is a shame that thanks to its initial unpopularity more people didn‚Äôt try this out and get to hear the games music. The sounds for the player and VA for the characters are on point and very good. You can tell what you are doing pretty easily by the sound and it doesn‚Äôt get in the way or rip out of the immersion. Certainly no argument here at all.

The story in this game was interesting and relevant, but that doesn't really matter as those two descriptions are assigned subjectively. The story is short and lacks implementation. Yes implementation, I don‚Äôt mind cut scenes but you could literally play the entire game without ever knowing about the story. It is that loosely attached! Not like it matters since the story itself leaves a few things unanswered but not on purpose. It becomes extremely forced once you get into the later levels. Overall the story is a good idea and concept but it was poorly created and implemented making it feel cheap or unappreciated. This does to me count as a tick against them because it isn‚Äôt much effort for a game studio to make a decent story, and Mirror‚Äôs Edge story is not even close to being passable.

Overall the game is 7.9/10 Not really mediocre just small and unpolished. The ideas behind it are great and a lot of what carries this game is actually the visuals, music, and maybe sometimes the movement. It‚Äôs certainly not a triple-a game, at least it wasn‚Äôt on its release, expecting a triple-a game is silly. If someone asked me if Mirror‚Äôs Edge is a good game for them to buy, I would ask them if what they were looking for was something quick to pick up or a new thing they can invest a few hours in. If you seek a quick game you don‚Äôt really want to get into then don‚Äôt bother getting this. But if you want something new and interesting you can really sink your teeth into then Mirror's Edge is the game for you.

Extra:
One of the things I liked the most about this game besides the art, music and gameplay is the fact that this was never even a triple-a game yet it felt like the game had been given access to the kind of resources a triple-a game gets when being developed. It wasn‚Äôt pandering and it had its own style instead of a bland mundane repetitive feeling you get from modern triple-a‚Äôs but with the quality of one. That‚Äôs what made is special to me. I LOVE THIS GAME!!! (hopefully its newfound popularity and hype won‚Äôt bog it's prequal(Mirror's Edge: Catalyst) down into another triple-a let down).

reviewText:
We step into the running shoes of Faith, a runner in this fast paced, acrobatic game, which is one of a kind. There aren't many games that combine the action adventure platforming with the first-person genre. The concept is well executed, too bad the game falls short in other areas.

In the unknown dystopian city, where crime virtually doesn't exists the Runners are the only ones that disturb the peace achieved by the totalitarian regime. It's a small group of anti-government individuals who can do one thing very well: run... and climb pipes and do acrobatic jumps, but that's (and committing crimes) part of the life style. Our protagonist is one of them, whose sister (a cop on top of that) is caught in political crossfire and arrested for the murder of the mayor candidate. From now on it's on Faith to discover the secrets that lie below the surface.

Unfortunately there are no hearth stopping, breath taking moments in the story. It's pretty plain and simple, nothing we haven't seen somewhere else (1984 - Orwell). Likewise the length and scope of the game doesn't allow the story to get to deeper levels. The game can be finished in a mere 4-5 hours. On the other hand the cartoony cut-scenes are a nice touch and the characters are believable thanks to the great voice acting.

Mirror's Edge consists of 9 chapters. In every chapter you have to get from point A to point B to complete an objective. It doesn't get any deeper than that, but at least the time spent between the start and finish is fun. The controls are reactive and you can take alternate routes to get an advantage over the riot police or just to be quicker and more efficient. In almost every level there is at least 1 point where you'll find yourself dying in 10-15 seconds after the checkpoint loads. Over and over again until you find the correct route or you can execute your jumps perfectly. These parts are pains, but the most frustrating thing in the gameplay are the gunfights. It's simply not meant to be there. Disarming guards and policemen, then shooting others feels off balanced, weak, and frustrating over all.

Faith's story has its flaws, but the game is at its best when you have to do what it's created for: platforming, wall running, jumping from pipe to pipe, rolling, sliding and so on. When you learn the levels and you become more proficient in spotting out the best routes it feels like you are a panther capable of anything. Unfortunately if you aren't in for the challenge of finding the best routes in each map there is not much else the in the game that could keep it installed on your computer for a long time. After finishing the story mode you can jump in and do some time trials, but as I said there isn't anything else beside that (if you don't count the bags which can be found in the story mode - 30 in total).

Rating: 68/100; Replay Value: 2/5; To Beat: 5 hours; Played on: normal.

reviewText:
A solid concept lacking polish breaks down into tedium and frustration
There is something to this game that really speaks to people, the free-running first person parkour, when it works, is absolutely amazing.
Unfortunately, there's a whole lot of stuff getting in the way of your fun.

It's not the plot, the plot is perfectly serviceable. Sure, it starts with your sister being framed for a murder and returns to that big bag of clich√©s for every new twist and development, but it wasn't bad and the little animated cutscenes did their job (...of masking loading screens, but they're neat too).

No, what breaks this game is the lack of polish that was applied to it. The finishing touches. There are many small gripes to be had here (lack of non-hostile characters within levels, level design not making sense from a functional perspective, big bulkhead doors that take half a minute to open, no subtitles for ambient speech like overheard conversations and announcements, shoddy and partially missing directions) but the two main ones are:

Bad checkpoints:
In a game that is ALL about flow, making your way through complex environments and a certain amount of trial and error in how to approach things it is absolutely critical that messing up does not frustrate too much. The checkpoints as they are now are far too few and far between to accomplish this, and some of them are spaced very weirdly.
There's a segment where you're climbing out of a large vertical shaft (it's in the Store page screenshots as well) and one of the checkpoints is right before a valve you need to turn to shut off a stream of water directly behind it. After that comes some tricky platforming, and I had to do that section several times. The problem here is that the game does not remember that you turned off the water, so you're stuck watching Faith perform the same ~8 second animation of turning off the water every single time, on top of the loading screen and unskippable bit where you're falling to your death that is far, far too much time to spend waiting and redoing things. This is only one of many places where I felt the game was far too sparing with the checkpoints, and to add insult to injury the in-chapter progress isn't even saved when you quit the game. You always start back at the beginning of the chapter.
The enemies:
In Faith's world the worst thing anybody can do is run across rooftops, it is immediate reason to send armed SWAT teams and attack helicopters after them. They shoot first, then shoot some more, and maybe ask questions later but that's not in the game. The justification for that is that you're supposedly carrying top-secret information and messages without the government surveillance catching it... except you don't do that in the game even once.
You're able to disarm these enemies when you get close or punch them out, and then pick up their guns and use them but I didn't bother with that and the game very much feels like it doesn't want you to (there's even an achievement for it... you know, on consoles. Because Steam integration is too much to ask from EA).
Regardless of whether you choose to engage or avoid these soldiers (they're hardly police forces any more) they will be in your way. Shooting for you as you duck and weave trying to make it to the next too-far-away checkpoint. I get why they're there, they are adding tension to the game.
Or parts of the game anyway, their appearance and disappearance is very jarring. Open up an inconspicuous door that is marked as your next target to find a dozen soldiers just lazing around a parking lot in case a Runner (that's you, because you run) decides to come through there. Run your way past them into the elevator, go up a floor (or however many floors, the insides aren't marked with a number) and you're completely in the clear again. The game seems divided into platforming segments and engagement segments, and the transitions are almost always immersion breaking.
In the late game the attempts at adding challenge become almost laughably silly, with every door you walk past popping open, revealing a tiny dark room with no other exits and one to three fully armed enemies that were sure you'd be coming this way. Add to that the new agile enemies, which should make the game more interesting since they can follow you around, but who end up doing pretty much the same thing anyway (and are as easily befuddled by you running through a door).
For DICE, a studio that was at that point best known for its Battlefield series, this was a huge and impressive step towards something more creative. A first person game built around avoiding fights, with a kick-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• female protagonist.
For Electronic Arts, a publisher known at that point for buying up smaller development studios and turning them into faceless drones that will never make another fun game in their life this was a great moment to show the world they could do something special, something different. Unfortunately, they did not.

With an extra 6 months of development and a whole lot more play-testing and polishing this could have been an absolute gem and must-play.
As it stands it is a 5-hour eulogy for what could have been.
Do not get this game, and be careful with the upcoming sequel, it might have similar problems.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is, without a doubt, one of my favourite games, ever. I'll glady recommend it to anyone looking for a new, visually spectacular, experience. I keep telling my friends this is one of the few games that they should've played at least once in their life. Unfortunately, no one ever listens. I don't mind though, because let's face it - it's their loss. And while there's definitely room for improvement, what's there is already very solid and lays the groundwork for a possible sequel, minus the story.

About the story: Mirror's Edge puts you in the shoes of Faith, who has to clear the name of her sister after being wrongfully accused of murdering someone. Doesn't sound all that exciting ? Well, I might agree with you there. However, it's the way the game is played that makes it fresh and interesting. You see, the game is played from a first person perspective. But instead of shooting your way out (which is optional, but not recommended, for maximum enjoyment) you'll be running. Parkour style. In other words: free running.
You'll be running through offices, on rooftops and many other places in order to get to where you want to go, all the while fighting off the police. This is all shown in one of the most beautifully realized environments I've ever laid eyes on (those office interiors ! *drool*). It's truly stunning.

Like I mentioned before, the game does have some flaws. First of all, it's short. Many people will complete it in a hour or 4-5. Not terribly long, but not terribly short also. It keeps the experience fun. I personally would've liked it if it was at least twice as long, but it's nothing a sequel can't fix. Besides, the time trials will keep you occupied for days, maybe even weeks. One other thing that can definitely be improved for a possible sequel is the number of routes you can take to get to your destination. Mirror's Edge gives you the illusion of an open world, but in fact there's only one way to get to your objective. Agreed, this way it keeps you focused on the story, but it certainly would've been nice.

Not much else I can say, really. This game is the reason why I play games. Play it yourself, and you just might agree with me. Maybe not today, but one day, I'm sure of it.

[Rating: 92/100)

Bought this after all the hype about this game. I was utterly disappointed. Here is a breakdown of pros and cons:

Pros:
- Great graphics even 6 years after its release

Cons:

- There is one way to do everything, no alternatives whatsoever, if you aren't able to read designer's mind, you are SOL
- The objective is never clear, you are spending the entire game figuring out where to go (most of which makes no sense). The designers must be too lazy to put any real puzzles to challenge the player.
- The checkpoint system is utterly frustrating - sometimes failing one obstacle could cause you to have to redo 10 obstacles, why not just allow the player to save?


After finishing the game, I had to ask myself, what's the point of this game? I basically spend 7 hours getting frustrated and annoyed most of the time, and there is minimal enjoyment. I'm deleting the game right away and will never touch it again. Too bad I wasted money on this.

Do you like parkour ? Do you like the colour white ? Do you like tattoos ? Do you like cartoons ? Do you like the sound of broken bones? If you like these key elemets , you will need to get the game :)
Joke aside , this is one of the games you must play at least once in your life time ...
The story , well to be honest it's pretty OK , the problem here is the writers , they presented it in a pretty mediocre way , and most of the story is told in the cutscenes which are cartoons (which ain't that much of a problem , at least for me). The story goes like this , your a Runner , which bassicly is a parkour ninja courier , one day your Lucy Liu look-alike sister gets in trouble and you need to help her. I was saying earlier that the writing is pretty bad , a good example of this is the few dramatic moments of the game , which could have been dramatic with some charcter development , which is almost inexistent . Tho this is a action-puzzle game , just like an action movie you won't expect some top grade story , you will expect some action !
Which is exactly where the game shines , in the gameplay, It's a very fresh experience , you  parkour your way out of level to level , sometimes you shoot your way out , with a suprisingly varied and realistic arsenal or by punching or kicking . It's pretty linear and the puzzles aren't that complicated , but that ain't that much of a problem, A suprisng thing is that even the gameplay is pretty linear , it's not repetitive at all. The replayability is there also , after you finished the game , you can play it again and try to speed run it in under an hour.
Talking about how long it is , if it's your first time around the game , it will take you in the vecinity of five hours.
Graphics , pretty bland , most of the time your feeling like your in a hospital with all that white , but you'll see some colours during the end.
Soundtrack , the classic combo between repetitive and boring ambient music and then the drumy and annoying fight music , this game truly needed a better soundtrack for example some really chill chillstep during the puzzle solving part and some hard core dubstep during the fights , but i guess that's just me.
A cool thing about this game is that technically is pretty well made , very few glitches and a very stable engine (no crashes here)
All in all , a pretty neat game , i higly reccomend buying it during a sale , you'll have a pleasant experience.

reviewText:
I'm honestly not sure if recommended is the right term for this game. This game feels like a testbed for an entire sub-genre, the First Person Platformer, its so far is the only unique example of it and it shows. When the game is in its stride it feels exhilarating to play with an amazing sense of direction and unique style in graphics that really has stopped it looking dated several years later.

Unfortunately the combat sequences can feel really out of place and can get frustrating very quickly and the game can quickly confuse the player about where exactly they need to be to the point where you have to look up videos on Youtube just to get an idea of where you are supposed to be. These two negatives can also get happen all at once which only serves to unduly stress the player. The story itself is also a letdown with no real talking points or standout characters excluding that of the protagonist Faith.

So with two glaring flaws why do I give this the thumbs up? I feel simply the concept that this game shows is full of potential, if DICE can iron out these flaws in the upcoming sequel it could really fly. There is something about this game that I just can't put my finger on, but it none of the less makes me excited to see if DICE can properly bake the formula into something incredible in the sequel.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is brilliant! It's a one of a kind game that combined first person and parkour remarkably well together. The graphics are stunning given that this game was released back in 2009. Besides that, the story is distinctively outstanding too. This game has a rather unique storyline that was carefully crafted for this game, but at the same time also allows you to realize how seemingly true it is and reflect on the fact that this is something that can one day happen to us as well.

According to Wikipedia and I edited it a little, the story of Mirror‚Äôs Edge takes place in an unnamed 'utopian' city where life is seemingly comfortable and crime almost non-existent. But the city's state of bliss is the achievement of a domineering and totalitarian government that monitors all communication, controls the media, have policies which include the outright illegalisation of smoking and alcohol. The City also operates sham trials, and runs on a sham democracy. Eighteen years before the events of the game they had also opened fire on a major protest against their deceitful rule, killing many civilians.

The story is actually rather similar to present-day situations in real life where in some parts of the world, democratic system is failing and corrupted governments are simply clinging onto their power through fake democracy or dictatorship where they exert extensive control on things like the media and internet and also prioritize monetary gain while neglecting human rights and the environment. So it shouldn't be surprising that the scenario in game can quite possibly happen to us one day if we continue progressing down the current path without making much effort to create positive changes.

Well, rant over lol. Anyway, it‚Äôs definitely worth giving this awesome game a try especially if you are blessed with the capability of not feeling motion sickness when there's a lot of movements on screen. Also, looking forward to Mirror's Edge Catalyst! :D

reviewText:
It's hard to believe Mirror Edge already is six years old but this game has been one of the greatest experiences for me ever since.

Mirror Edge was original because it was the first game to introduce parkour into a first person game. For the most part of the game you're unarmed trying to escape from trigger happy police. You are able to slide kick or punch enemies and you are even able to take their weapons. Guns carry a few bullets so you won't kill that many opponents but that's alright since it's not what this game is about.

Most of my favourite games have a great story but Mirror Edge is an exception. It's not like the story is bad but it's not great either. What makes Mirror Edge one of my favourites is simple: Atmosphere. It's just amazing to run around sky high buildings, escaping from the police. The buildings all look white and clean even the indoor industrial areas look clean which are just great to look at. Even falling down from tall buildings was something I enjoyed and made dying a lot easier.... in a way.

The graphics are still great for a 2009 + Mirror Edge has a great OST.

This game is not recommended to people who want to kill lots of enemies but everyone else who is open to new things should really try this game at least once in your life.

reviewText: Mirror's Edge is one of a kind type of game.  Superb graphics that really utilizes color well to create a surreal world while also using color to help guide you through the levels.  You are running from the authoritarian government and must not be caught throughout the game.  This is where this game is unique.  This is not a first person game where weapons will save your life, though weapons are available if you steal one from the government goons.  This is a game about parcour.  You run, jump, slide and slam your way through doors.  If you do so fluidly, you will gain more momentum, more speed, and the game seems perfect and so organic when this happens.  However, it's difficult to attain this type of fluidity.  The game is challenging, but this is what makes the game so attractive to me.  The challenge, the uniqueness and the sheer beauty of the game makes this an easily recommended title for all to try at least once.  This is a must have game for all gamers.

reviewText: I wanted so badly to like this game.  I love the idea, I love the graphics, I love the setting - but the gameplay is just godawful frustrating.  The controls are sluggish and finicky in places. reviewText:
I really can't say I know of any games quite like this one. It may be short, but it leaves one heck of an impact, and will easily draw you in for more. Having previously played it on the Xbox 360, I can attest that while you can finish the whole story in one sitting with relative ease, you'll likely be playing the bits you liked over and over again.

The story is where the game really shines. You quickly learn that the primarily trigger-based controls are, while unique, pretty intuitive after a while. Everything in the game feels natural pretty quickly. Finding a path, stringing together acrobatic moves, and generally making your way around. Only the combat really feels stilted, with a same few punch animations. You're mostly encouraged simply to disarm opponents by tapping the Y button when their weapon is highlighted, which gives you their gun and instantly knocks them out. This can get tedious, but pacifist runs are possible.

The cutscenes have an animated comic sort of look to them. This is decent enough for getting the point across. The plot exists, primarily to get you between things to run around. It does a well enough job, and has quite a few surprises for only ten levels. The actual story levels themselves are like a combined puzzle platformer, as you mull over how to get where you're going and pull off some intensely satisfying parkour once you get the hang of it. The color scheme and lighting keeps the areas distinct from each other and easy on the eyes. It's a very particular, stylized look that benefits the game well.

As for replay value, as the main story is short and sweet (it does not overstay its welcome by any stretch, but you may be expecting a bit more at the end), the game banks on you enjoying time trials. Really, really enjoying time trials. Because that's all there is. No other challenges in any way, shape, or form, just be the fastest. To be fair, it's quite clear the game is designed for this exact purpose when you start shaving valuable seconds off and learning how to keep momentum going throughout your run, but if you don't like them, already got the three runner bags hidden in each level, and, for whatever reason, don't feel a little thrill at pulling an awesome time off, you've pretty much finished the game as soon as the credits roll.

The music is excellently fitting. The game overall can put a fantastic feeling of adrenaline into you, and a feeling of success when you figure out a new way through a level. There's no faster way to give someone a fear of heights than having them fall to their death in this game. The loading times are almost gone in the PC version (only three Loading Level" screens still appeared for me)

reviewText:
I first played this game back in 2009 when it came out and I still play it to this very day from time to time.

Gameplay is smooth with the perfect mix of realism and arcade elements to still make it a game. It really feels like you flow through the levels, quickly fight back (or escape) an enemy and get back on track running towards your goal. The game has also some of the greatests vistas of urban landscapes I have ever witnessed in a videogame. The level design is remarkably beautiful to date.

Some negative aspects I could drag your attention to are its lenght and the way the story is presented. The game is short, no doubt. Although it offers a certain level or replayability because of its open level design, each time you play it you will finish it faster (but we can say that about just any game, can't we?). As for the story, it feels like it is just there; a filler that gives you a reason to run from point A to point B. But you do not really get into it and what you actually do in the game does not feel too much related to its further development.

However, I do not think they are game breaking or that the experience suffers as a whole from these two elements, otherwise I would not have been playing it for the past 5 years, let alone recommend it.

reviewText: This is one of those rare games. It's not about parkour. It's not about killing the enemy. It's not about getting to the end. No, Mirror's Edge is much more. It's more about the place in which the atmosphere and music takes me. I can be standing on top of a rooftop looking out to the corrupt and broken city with its glimmering skyscrapers and effecient infrastructure. Or I can be hiding in out in a maintenance room listening to the whirling sounds of various pieces of machinery compliment the ambient soundtrack. No matter where I am in this game, I am always taken away, and it's that reason alone, that tiny reason, is why I love this game to death.

reviewText:
Although the campaign is easily 4 hours long on normal difficulty, I would still recommend this game to anybody of all tastes. This is a unique blend of first-person action and platformer style puzzle solving. Although the story isn't very engaging, it fits the atmosphere of the game perfectly. The visuals are stunning if not photorealistic at times. It performs very well and you will encounter very little problems and bugs along the way

Pros

+Stunning Graphics.
+Easy to learn, hard to master gameplay.
+Engaging and captivating atmosphere.
+Appropriate storyline which fits well into the game's universe.
+Arcade mode for speedruns

Cons
-Poor AI sometimes throwing the game off balance.
-Short Story mode 4-5 hours on first playthough.
-Lack of graphics customisation
-Little extra content
-Very linear

Ultimately I would recommend this game, especially as it it dirt cheap. It is well worth a play through and I guarantee it will leave a lasting impression on the player for years to come.

I usually get nauseated and dizzy in these type of first person games however I didn't playing this game so take with that what you will.

On the other hand, the game itself has a very compelling protagonist, with a wonderfully drawn script that kept me going throughout the game. The level designs are absolutely breathtaking, from the skyscrapers to the underground levels.

The combat is very fluid and for once in any sort of game, I feel that having a weapon is actually a detriment. You move so much slower, attack so much slower. Without one you feel very fluid, able to weave in and out of a battle and depending on how skilled you are.

Overall the games fun as hell, the levels are beautifully designed. Honestly you should pick up this game

reviewText:
I finally got around to beating this game after like two years. I got about 2/3 of the way done before, got stuck on an area, got salty, and quit. Picked it up again and finished it in 3 hours or so.

It's usually not hard to see WHERE you're supposed to end up, it's just finding the path there and not falling to your death from a bad jump. I'd say there's replay value, because as soon as you finish the game you're just really getting the mechanics down and tend to make less mistakes.

I see a lot of people complain about combat - I sort of get it, the combat isn't exactly fun but it's also not the point of the game in my opinion. You're a runner. You should be avoiding every enemy you can and taking the others out with acrobatic grace.

Should be, anyway. I suck at disarming enemies so I just had to punch folks until they fell down. It was underwhelming, but I also think being chased and attacked was necessary to the feeling you get while running away. Glass crashing around you and bullets flying, Faith escapes again into the corners of the city.

I adored the art style and selective use of colors. People saying it's all red and white are blind or didn't actually play the game. The colors do a lot of foreshadowing and kind of mentally prep you for upcoming events. I plan on doing some speed trials just to get pretty screenshots.

PhysX is a turd and will blow your computer up, even if you have a PhysX optimized GPU. If you get huge FPS drops when windows break, it's PhysX. Disable it and enjoy the game.

It's so easy to not notice the soundtrack. A lot of the time you're just being talked to via headset, or you hear the sounds of the city. But there are a couple areas where the song is inspiring, where it makes you feel like you're flying and the air is rushing past your ears and through your hair.

The story is so-so. Think 90's action flick and you've got an idea of it. There are a couple plot holes but they're pretty easy to overlook and don't affect the enjoyment of the game for me personally. I just wanna jump off walls and do cool stuff.

If you're into acrobatic gameplay and using speed rather than force, definitely give this game a shot. It's fun and the style is so memorable.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a one-of-a-kind game with it's own expirience when you play it. Get involved into some action and fast-paced parcour on roofs, inside buildings and on the streets! All that comes in addition with a bright style of graphics and a handfull of other, very fitiing, colours.

To begin with, the mechanics and the idea are a very neat thing, and it keeps you occupied for the time you play the story, as you get to use the variety of interactions, like wallrunning, pipe climbing, walljumping, disarming, sliding, etc. in a totally random order, depending on the levels.

The con at that part is, that the level design forces you to take a passage, the game is rather linear when it comes to that. There sometimes are several possibilites to get around though, still they end with the same result/position to be in.

The idea behind collecting secrets to unlock artwork/extras is a neat idea, still, I do believe that it does not really improve the fact, that the replayability is kind of low, as you barely get to see something new when you play for a second time.

The multiplayer, if you can call it like that, is more like a racer. No cool disarming, no avoiding or dodging of gunfire. You race other people, with the hope to win. Nothing else to say at that point.

In total, I can recommend Mirror's Edge at the price it is at. It is worth buying and enjoying, as it is a different expirience.

reviewText:
For those of you who don't know, Mirror's Edge is a single-player, first person, action-adventure platform video game. Don't knock it off just because it was developed by EA (Because a lot of people just hate EA for... Being EA I guess). The general overview is that you're Faith Connors, an individual classified as a Runner in a resistance network against the city where a totalitarian government is in place. Essentially, your very existence is illegal, and the police, the SWAT teams, and even the news helicopters, are going to do everything they can to eliminate you. Your only choice? Run.

Instead of starting off with the graphics and soundtrack and whatnot, I'll start off with mentioning what a brilliant idea Mirror's Edge tries to convey. The game makes you think beyond just the game itself. In the city, where all buildings are either a blinding white, or have shiny surfaces similar to a mirror, everything seems sterile and under control. When you play as Faith, parkouring over rooftops and transforming this orderly design into her own route, it presents a question of security vs. freedom of the individual. It makes you question how much people should sacrifice just to feel safe? Should they give up their privacy like so many others? Or should they struggle against it, despite the danger?

Now, for a game that was released in 2008, the graphics are quite good. If your computer has graphics cards that can handle all the PhysX stuff, the shattering glass and the bullets embedding themselves into sides of buildings are quite realistic. That's essentially all I can really say, but the more important part is that if your computer can't handle it, (And I doubt it since the System Requirements come with almost all laptops these days), then turning everything on low doesn't give you a massive headache just from the pixels you can see.

Graphics aside, (Because graphics don't matter as much to me as long as I don't get a headache because the game is too pixelated or something) the next thing I'd like to talk about is the soundtrack and the environment. As I mentioned before, the city gives off this sterile, no-touchy feeling. At the same time, when you're running across rooftops and leaping from building to building, there is this otherworldly feeling of almost flying. As you're running, Faith's rhythmic footsteps and breathing just give you a sense of freedom as the wind actually whooshes by you and the music just emphasizes that quality. This feeling is sharply contrasted when you're under attack, and the peacefulness is broken, and the music does make you feel either the freedom of just running, or the terror of getting caught.

There were some areas of the game that I felt lacking. The main problem I had was the short storyline. When I ended the game, I was satisfied, but at the same time, it left me wanting something more. Good news is that Mirror's Edge 2 is coming out soon... Sure, it's a prequel to Mirror's Edge, but now we get some background information on our heroine!

Another area I had was the gameplay itself, more specifically, the combat. The point of the game is to run, but there are times when you have no other choice but to fight. After all, there's only so many bullets you can try to outrun. Perhaps it's because I almost never remembered to use the slow-motion" key

reviewText:
The Good:

1) Parkour: This is what makes the game so damn fun. DICE put a lot of work making it feel real and fun at the same time, and it pays off really well. The fact that its first person makes you feel like you're actually doing it. Despite the combat not being up to par, the parkour works so well that you almost forget about it

2) Graphics: For a game that came out in 2008, this still looks great. Not only does the world feel real, but the art style is just so memorable. It makes me wish a city like this was real

3) Soundtrack: For an electronic soundtrack, it creates a relaxing feeling. It fits the tone and world perfectly

4) Level design: While the game is very linear, it makes up for it with well thought out levels that give you multiple paths to get to your destination.

The Bad:

1) Length: It's only 5-6 hours. Should've been at least 8-10 hours

2) Combat: I wish you could chain your parkour with your fighting skills to take down enemies while still moving fast, instead of having to come to a complete stop every time you want to do a takedown. Also, the punching and kicking animations feel stiff. Using guns is even worse; I wish they would have improved the hand-to-hand combat and removed guns completely.

Despite its flaws, this is my favourite game of all time. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a unique action-adventure game.

9/10

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a one-of-a-kind game with it's own expirience when you play it. Get involved into some action and fast-paced parcour on roofs, inside buildings and on the streets! All that comes in addition with a bright style of graphics and a handfull of other, very fitiing, colours.

To begin with, the mechanics and the idea are a very neat thing, and it keeps you occupied for the time you play the story, as you get to use the variety of interactions, like wallrunning, pipe climbing, walljumping, disarming, sliding, etc. in a totally random order, depending on the levels.

The con at that part is, that the level design forces you to take a passage, the game is rather linear when it comes to that. There sometimes are several possibilites to get around though, still they end with the same result/position to be in.

The idea behind collecting secrets to unlock artwork/extras is a neat idea, still, I do believe that it does not really improve the fact, that the replayability is kind of low, as you barely get to see something new when you play for a second time.

The multiplayer, if you can call it like that, is more like a racer. No cool disarming, no avoiding or dodging of gunfire. You race other people, with the hope to win. Nothing else to say at that point.

In total, I can recommend Mirror's Edge at the price it is at. It is worth buying and enjoying, as it is a different expirience.

reviewText:
For those of you who don't know, Mirror's Edge is a single-player, first person, action-adventure platform video game. Don't knock it off just because it was developed by EA (Because a lot of people just hate EA for... Being EA I guess). The general overview is that you're Faith Connors, an individual classified as a Runner in a resistance network against the city where a totalitarian government is in place. Essentially, your very existence is illegal, and the police, the SWAT teams, and even the news helicopters, are going to do everything they can to eliminate you. Your only choice? Run.

Instead of starting off with the graphics and soundtrack and whatnot, I'll start off with mentioning what a brilliant idea Mirror's Edge tries to convey. The game makes you think beyond just the game itself. In the city, where all buildings are either a blinding white, or have shiny surfaces similar to a mirror, everything seems sterile and under control. When you play as Faith, parkouring over rooftops and transforming this orderly design into her own route, it presents a question of security vs. freedom of the individual. It makes you question how much people should sacrifice just to feel safe? Should they give up their privacy like so many others? Or should they struggle against it, despite the danger?

Now, for a game that was released in 2008, the graphics are quite good. If your computer has graphics cards that can handle all the PhysX stuff, the shattering glass and the bullets embedding themselves into sides of buildings are quite realistic. That's essentially all I can really say, but the more important part is that if your computer can't handle it, (And I doubt it since the System Requirements come with almost all laptops these days), then turning everything on low doesn't give you a massive headache just from the pixels you can see.

Graphics aside, (Because graphics don't matter as much to me as long as I don't get a headache because the game is too pixelated or something) the next thing I'd like to talk about is the soundtrack and the environment. As I mentioned before, the city gives off this sterile, no-touchy feeling. At the same time, when you're running across rooftops and leaping from building to building, there is this otherworldly feeling of almost flying. As you're running, Faith's rhythmic footsteps and breathing just give you a sense of freedom as the wind actually whooshes by you and the music just emphasizes that quality. This feeling is sharply contrasted when you're under attack, and the peacefulness is broken, and the music does make you feel either the freedom of just running, or the terror of getting caught.

There were some areas of the game that I felt lacking. The main problem I had was the short storyline. When I ended the game, I was satisfied, but at the same time, it left me wanting something more. Good news is that Mirror's Edge 2 is coming out soon... Sure, it's a prequel to Mirror's Edge, but now we get some background information on our heroine!

Another area I had was the gameplay itself, more specifically, the combat. The point of the game is to run, but there are times when you have no other choice but to fight. After all, there's only so many bullets you can try to outrun. Perhaps it's because I almost never remembered to use the slow-motion" key

reviewText:
Ever heard of a first person platformer? Not really, no. So that's a pretty wide gap to bridge. Mirror's Edge does a nice job to jump the gap, but it sure is no bridge.

Mirror's Edge puts you in the bright red shoes of Faith, an inhabitant of an Orwellesque city who runs and jumps on rooftops to deliver secret packages to people who try to liberate the population from the regime. The premise is interesting, but the game refrains from giving you a clear motive or goal; it just drip-feeds it to you. It is not paced very well. You don't really understand what you're doing until the credits roll. Call it Chekov writing if you must, I call it demotivational.

The controls are simple, yet effective. This isn't like platforming in Half Life where pressing the jump button launches you into space and pushing up to ladders makes you go up; this is about momentum and clever jumps and acrobatics. The freerunning is done fluently and intuitively. However, your runner's high tends to be tackled by the game's awkward and completely redundant combat system. It is a shame cause it would have been so much more fun if you could just...keep on running.

You run through a weird city that is coloured white and then some other colours. It looks very stylish and makes it pleasant to look at while you jump from building to building.
Mirror's Edge has an interesting concept going for it, but it seems to lack refinement and pacing. Still, it's worth a shot just for the experience of FPS running.

reviewText:
I very much enjoyed the game.

I liked:
* a very unusual concept, a great idea
* nicely executed, both graphically, in sound and in gameplay
* an interesting story
* the thrilling feeling when flying in the air between two skyscrapers, a hundred meters of free space below you, and the other building is almost out of reaaaach... awesome

What could have been better:
* a quite short game
* not as fast (in terms of running) as I imagined. Usually I was looking for a way forward or fighting the cops, completely ruining the running experience. I would like to enjoy longer sequences of insane jumps, slides, wall jumps, etc, without having to constantly stop and look around to find the correct path forward. Yes, you can do the speed runs and time trials afterwards, but having that in the main story would be much better.
* some cutscenes were unskippable and if you died shortly afterward, you saw them again and again. The same for game starting video sequences. Come on, developers.

See the trailer and if you like the concept, definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Lots of fun. While many people say it's not replayable, I've gone through the game a good ten times and enjoyed each run. Memorizing spots to speed up your runs that you may not have known existed during your first playthrough and seeing a great running combo pay off is very rewarding, which adds a sense of replayability to the game and also makes second and third runs faster and more fun.

On the flip side, by giving players such an intensely graceful experience, after a few runs the player starts to play overly recklessly and hectically as they try to keep the flow going, which often results in death and frustration. Going fast for the whole level is incredibly addicting, and I hope Mirror's Edge 2 either adaps to or changes this. Give the player an incentive to ever stop going very quickly, like a decent combat system or a small chance to explore and see what the safest/fastest routes through a level are and make your choice. Otherwise, make sure the game flows as neatly as possible and feels graceful and fast the whole way.

For what it is, Mirror's edge is definitely worth the buy, especially at $4.99, which I've seen it go for many times.

reviewText:
This game is absolutley beautiful. Almost everything in this game is done perfectly even if it is not intentional.

Pros:

Graphics hold up well
Fluid movement
Infinite replayability
The glitches improve the game (more on that later)
Great FPS on almost any computer

Cons:

The combat is clunky and boring
Hit-boxes can be odd at times
Pipe clumbing is unbearably slow
Hackers ruin any chance at in game world record times
Difficulty goes from good to what is this when going from normal to hard

As mentioned earlier, the glitches greatly improve this game. What I mean by this is that the capability of using the glitches (which actually require skill to pull off) can allow you to improve your speed on runs greatly. It is one of the best feelings ever to successfully pull of a difficult kick-glitch that shaves of 10 seconds of your time. The only time I have encountered a hindering bug was while performing a non-hindering bug so, what can you expect.

Aside from that, if you aren't interested in speedrunning this game still includes some of the smoothest freerunnung in any game to date. The genre created by this game is the best of it's kind and has not been bested, which only proves this game's greatness more.

TL;DR This game is godly get it immediatley.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a beautiful game. It's fast paced and doesn't have to ever slow down if you are a good enough free-runner. But, this game isn't perfect, and as a hug fan of this game I'm going to be completely honest.

The good things about Mirror's Edge:
The Look - The City is amazingly gorgeous and dynamic. Different color schemes for certain buildings really help piece the city together.
The Feel - The controls are decent enough to get you where you need to go without looking like an idiot, but it's the animations and the lightweight feel of Faith that really make you feel like a runner. The way she vaults and slides across the floor look fantastic.
The Soundtrack - One of my favorite videogame OST's, Mirror's Edge has a distinctive feel that's core comes from listening to it's music.

The Bad things about Mirror's Edge:
Wonky parkour controls - At times you'll find that what you want to pull off isn't achievable unless you're a skilled pro at the game. You want to wall run then coil over that fence? Until you're completely familarized with the controls you'll fail 90% of the time.
No Achievements - You wanted to get achievements and cards for your amazing parkouring in this game? You would be better off buying it on console. That's right, Steam doesn't offer any achievements or trading cards for this game. Probably because the game is so old, the port to Steam is missing a lot of things that would make playing Mirror's Edge worth your while.
The combat - Now, this is completely avoidable if you have the skill to evade the police, but the combat isn't all that great. Sure, when you have the chance to pull of wallrun-kicks and leap onto SWAT members it can be enjoyable. But the areas at which you face the police are so open and empty you'll end up walking up to them, waiting for them to hit you with a melee attack, and easily tapping a button and countering them. Then you'll drop their gun, rinse, and repeat this process until all of the police are taken down and you can get on your way.
Short storyline - The story is pretty uninteresting in my opinion. It only picks up at certain parts, and it's easy to tell who the villain is going to be by the final chapters. The game is only 9 missions long, and these missions are usually 10 - 30 minutes long.

In the end, Mirror's Edge is a great game that you will enjoy if you're into parkour and first person combat games. But if you want rewards, achievements, cards, or badges, steer clear of this title. By the end of the game, you'll feel one of two emotions. Satisfied with a great short-but-sweet experience, or you'll be left wanting more out of the game, since you can only now speed-run the same sections of the game or do time trials on certain parts of missions. Also, mentioning the no achievements you'll feel like you just sped-ran the whole game and all of the time trials for nothing, seeing how your scores on the leaderboard are only going to be buried beneath hackers of the game.

6/10 - Good but could be a lot better if Steam supported the features that other titles have on it's store.
