reviewText:
A very solid platformer with some action thrown in for good measure.  This game forces you to think in real time to get to your goal while dodging trigger happy cops in some parts.  You could also relieve the cops of their weapons and show them how to put it to better use if you're more of an aggressive player.  The levels are fairly linear, but the overall gameplay experience is one that is quite enjoyable.

It would be a good idea to play this one with a controller.

Pros:
Solid freerunning platforming action in first person.
PhysX support, for those with Nvidia cards
Combat sequences don't clash with the actual gameplay, and you can choose to take out your attackers in most cases.
A few extra challenges added in to really test your ability to cover ground.
Time Trial mode once you ace story mode.
Excellent graphics and environments.

Cons:
Low replayability

Afterthoughts
Play this one with a controller, as the controls are better suited for a controller as opposed to a keyboard.  AMD/ATI folks should turn off PhysX, it will really cull your performance.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is one of those games that was made a few years ago, but still wipes the floor with most recent games. Don't let EA's involvement in the game throw you off, this one was from before the dark days that give us nightmares every night.

While the storyline of the game is not amazing, it is still pretty decent and is still more interesting than a lot of storylines in current games. The main appeal of this game for me was the apparent freedom of movement you have, even though the levels are quite linear. The wide-open level design makes you feel like the path you take is not necessarily the one and only path through the level, even though most of the time it is. The time trial levels reuse some of the storyline levels, which makes them somewhat repetitive yet familliar in an environment where practising easily makes you more comfortable with the section you are running.

The freerunning mechanics don't feel clunky and with the focus on momentum, they feel really fast and smooth when you are playing well and have a reasonable drop in this when you are not (which still does not make the freerunning feel clunky).

Considering the game was released in 2009 for PC, you don't need one of those new-fangled super-toaster 5000 with four bread slots and fast-defrost action- glueing a few potatoes together should suffice. Since the game is over five years old, it is pretty cheap now, too. Unless you don't like this kind of game, there isn't much argument for not giving it a go.

reviewText:
I recommend this game.
It has found its place among my top three most interesting games.

The gameplay itself is very immersing and may be worded in a very simplyfied way as problem solving under timelimits.
It is however very heavy in getting the right timing for performing the right action. Altough one may slow time down for a short while i rarely use it because it disrupts the gameflow (in my humble opinion).
I could not play this game in full resolution (1920x1080) when there where multiple enemys appearing. Even so there are only barely visible differences when playing on 1360x768 pixels thanks to the way the levels are buildt.

One fustrating thing is the setting of Savepoints, that force you (especially in the later chapters) to start some long passages over once you die/fail. On the other hand really being forced to get longer sequences  and timings right gives this game its charm and made me think back to the first Rayman i played on a Gameboy advance.

All in all a fun first person parkour game/ 3D Platform jump and run, that gives you the freedom to either fight your way trough or run past all obstacles without harming anyone. Wheras the main point is to match your timing and finding your way.

Ps.: Because I played offline my game time was not recorded.

reviewText:

In the world of Mirror's Edge you live in a dystopian city that appears innocent and comfortable yet is corrupted by surveilance at every corner. reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is one of those games that was made a few years ago, but still wipes the floor with most recent games. Don't let EA's involvement in the game throw you off, this one was from before the dark days that give us nightmares every night.

While the storyline of the game is not amazing, it is still pretty decent and is still more interesting than a lot of storylines in current games. The main appeal of this game for me was the apparent freedom of movement you have, even though the levels are quite linear. The wide-open level design makes you feel like the path you take is not necessarily the one and only path through the level, even though most of the time it is. The time trial levels reuse some of the storyline levels, which makes them somewhat repetitive yet familliar in an environment where practising easily makes you more comfortable with the section you are running.

The freerunning mechanics don't feel clunky and with the focus on momentum, they feel really fast and smooth when you are playing well and have a reasonable drop in this when you are not (which still does not make the freerunning feel clunky).

Considering the game was released in 2009 for PC, you don't need one of those new-fangled super-toaster 5000 with four bread slots and fast-defrost action- glueing a few potatoes together should suffice. Since the game is over five years old, it is pretty cheap now, too. Unless you don't like this kind of game, there isn't much argument for not giving it a go.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a game built solely on free running/parkour and fleeing from a new government's regime.This includes reaching your destinations in unusual ways through roofs, obstacles and other wide or narrow spaces. All of this often leads to an encounter with armed forces which sometimes can be avoided or challenged through a combat.

‚òÖ Movement has a good flow until you reach combat. However, it can be sloppy from time to time and because of that your character might miss objects that you're supposed to hang onto like poles.

‚òÖ Combat is probably one of the worst aspects of this game. The melee part is kinda fine until you take possession of a gun. Its mechanics are literally crap. It would've been better if there were less combat because you can't avoid everything and you'll be forced to engage in it at some point anyways.

‚òÖ As for the story, it didn't seem to be interesting for me at all. I was really trying to get into it and make it grow on me but I still found it dull (many will disagree).

‚òÖ Music and graphics had a huge impact for this game's success. Soundtracks are relaxing and fits the theme. Moreover, colorful and minimalist graphic design added so much to this game visually that it distracted me from the gameplay just to enjoy the view.

Therefore, this game stands on the verge between + and - but I'll still recommend it since I enjoyed it to some extent.

6.5/10

reviewText:
I remember when this game first came out in 2009. I didn't even know what it was, not the slightest idea. I picked it up on PS3 for roughly $80 AUD going from only the pictures that were on the back of the cover. When I got home of course I just had to boot it up straight away and at the time the first thing I remember was my eyes just lighting up, like I've just seen the best thing ever and nothing could top this. I was hooked and nothing stopped me from finishing the game in one sitting, the next day I had to tell everyone I loved it.

The game itself has aged well, it's still the same old original game I played back then. It's still stunning to look at, it's bright and unique like nothing you have seen before. The soundtrack is beautiful and calming and the sense of speed gets your heart racing. The keyboard and mouse works great and so does a controller straight out of the box, there's plenty of options to set and the game overall is optimized pretty well if not great. Now the story is simple sometimes it's comic styled and other times it's in game cutscenes but it's as average as you'd get for a parkour game... still it does it's job well, the plot gets you by surprise and the ending has a nice tone to it.

Now a few things that are not the best, the first thing is well clearly it's not a game for everyone and that's fine you might just go into it and think well this is stupid. The gun mechanics are underwhelming so most of the time you'll find yourself avoiding it altogether. For AMD users as always the NVIDIA physics will destroy your fps but you can just simply switch it off which is good.

Overall I think the game is amazing it might be the nostalgia talking but if you see this on sale for cheap, give it a try I'm sure you'll end up liking it just as much as I did.

It would be wicked with the Occulus Rift, or something similiar.\n\nWith that being said, as an indie-game-enthusiast, I probably won't play more than I already have. I got this for (I think) less than five bucks - I didn't know it was an Electronic Arts title, or I would not have bothered.

reviewText:
Six years late, but better late than never. The combat and story are a little weak but I didn't buy this game for its combat and story. I bought it to do parkour and, oh my, is it a fantastic free running simulator. Once you get a feel for it, you can seamlessly scale walls, vault over obstacles and jump from building to building to reach your destination.

The visuals holds up surprisingly well for a six year old game. The colors are vibrant and gives the game a distinct look. The soundtrack is amazing and really sets the atmosphere of the game.

10/10

reviewText:
First person parkour gaming at its finest.

Short version

Run around, get creative on how to get from A to B using parkour tactics while avoiding enemies that attack you. What's not to like?


Long version

The story is a bit weak and predictable with some big plot holes and on the short side but you are not going to care about that. You'll be too busy running around the city map missions using creative ways to get around, under and above obstacles.

Enemies can be avoided, fought or just killed; it's up to you. The PC version does not have the trophies achievements from the console versions, you will unlock everything by just finishing the game on any difficulty. So go nuts and kill if you want, there is no penalty or Steam achievements.

The game uses checkpoints, but they are not located far from each other so no frustrating long re-attempts at difficult points.

The stage designs.....GORGEOUS!!!  Bright clean colors and great architecture. Even background (or rather the far ground floor looking down from skyscrapers) has actual people and traffic life to it. You don't feel like you're in a dead city. Even birds and airplanes are sometimes visible in the sky. Seriously, who ever made the maps, is a genius. I really enjoyed just being there like it is a real city. The atmosphere alone is totally worth playing this game.

reviewText:
I love games that have great movement mechanics. Easy to learn and tough to master.

Mirror's Edge is that and more. Its a brief stomp through a sterile and white looking city under control by big organizations. You're constantly on the run toward objectives away or through police forces, using your momentum and their own weapons against them.

Gorgeous and great fun to run and jump and roll and punch.

reviewText:
This is very good. The premise of a first-person Parkour game is really original, and the level design really has you believing you're clinging to the edge of a tall building. Some of the moves you can do in this game are just thrilling. The mouse and keyboard controls work well and don't feel like they came from a console port.

There's about 6 hours of content here.

The bad:
- Contains quicktime events.
- The gamepad controls aren't great (use the mouse).
- The combat sections aren't much fun (but putting the game on easy mode makes them go by quicker)
- The game locks up every time you switch tasks.
- The online leaderboards are full of cheaters, making time trial mode less fun than it could be.

reviewText:
Surprisingly good game, I really enjoyed it despite its shortness (it takes about 5-7 hours to beat it, may be 10 hours with finding all collectives, but if you're interested in speedrun walkthrough, current world record is about 35 minutes with skipping all cut scenes and using all short cuts, if I'm not mistaken).

Strong colours everywhere, protagonist is so full of life, whole city is beautiful(although a little empty on pedestrians), very immersive first person view, stylish 2d in game clips.

Reminds me about Portal, where you have impressive (no sarcasm) running skills instead of portal gun. Climbing isn't as boring as in Assassin's creed, story is good too, although I find it a little unfinished.

Levels are mix of running, labyrinth puzzles and fighting/running away from enemies. And some more running. Yes, even more on top of that.

I enjoyed every minute of gameplay(except the time where I got stuck in puzzles).
Extras" menu in game allows you to check some beautiful concept arts

reviewText:
Mirrors Edge is a game, which is a bit different from all the other FPS...though...i wouldn't even call it FPS...more like First-Person-Parcour-Simulation-with-bits-of-Combat.

So, if you like the idea of Parcour and running through levels, running along walls, jumping over obstacles or sliding below them, give this game a try.
If not, then don't even bother continue reading.

You're taking over the Role of Faith, a so called Runner (which is sort of a courier which brings informations or items to their clients).
As already said, you will run and jump and slide through the levels in First-Person View, which is actually quite fun and pretty well executed.
It does feel pretty good to do wallruns, jumps and slides and try to get the proper timing.

Though it has it's flaws, the story is rather thin, the combat (which isn't mandatory, you can outrun them or punch them to the floor in most cases) can be pretty frustrating and checkpoints are sometimes set a bit stupid (though most of the time pretty fair).

It's definitely worth a look, especially because it does things different and it was definitely a risk doing such a game, and for me this needs to be rewarded, even though it's nowhere near perfect.

Talk to me about another free running game that is in 3D and that has managed to impress millions of fans around the world. Nop? Well, there's Mirror's Edge, an unique adventure with excellent graphics and things to do, to think about and to explore (kind of)

The bad :

- Missions are somewhat repetitive, some are too easy, some are way too difficult
- Storyline hard to believe but still interesting enough ( cuz it's a cartoon for God's sake!)
- Although the city looks well planned and beautiful, no free running 'round unfortunately. Yes, I fel immersed into an urban futuristic city probably like never before, but in-mission. I never could explore things on my own

reviewText:
Worth the full price?
Yes, but if it's on sale you should definitely get it!

Why play this game?
Parkour, action, stunning art/graphics design, amazing sountrack!

Problems: None worth mentioning. Game runs very smoothley.

Playtime/replayability: Playtime around 5-7 hours to get through the story mode depending on how good you are and if you look for the hidden collectibles. You can race/time trial levels so if you're into that kind of thing expect more playtime.

reviewText:
Parkour, cyberpunk, high-octane adventure/action thriller with a female hero protagonist.

Pros

* Sexy asian female heroine, lead protagonist provides a distinction to just about every other game out there since Tomb Raider which I found refreshing and captivating.
* Visuals are excellent, and could have been even better if my system would have handled it.
* Storyline was simple but easy to follow and still captivating.
* Simple and straight forward, it's main tenant is one or two things and it doesn't try to pretend to be anything more.
* Has been made to work in VR, which I am very excited to try.
* Really liked that it had combat strewn in there as well. I began to really look forward to weapon encounters just so I could steal the weapon and shoot every one up - kinda breaks up the rhythm of the game.
* Exhillarating, fun, almost-realistic, inspires a rush of adrenaline and fear.
* Breathtaking and awe-inspiring cityscape views.
* Beautifully animated cutscenes.
* It was really fun, and the combination of parkour, gun battles, fighting and chases was enthralling.
* Cinematic quality gameplay that really flowed from one scene to the next, creating a sense of urgency - really well done!

Cons

* The wall-running and other parkour techniques that are fundamental to the game are not explored thoroughly enough in the tutorial, which can lead to frustrations later on in the game and slowed it down, when the challenges become more difficult.
* Extremely laggy on an 2xGPU ATI gfx card with PhysX turned on (in particular the scenes where lots of glass breaks) - had to disable PhysX - then it ran excellent.
* Storyline may be a little too simplistic for some. Could have used a few extra twists perhaps, but I was satisfied just the way it was, but could definitely have been a little longer.
* Some of the city detail could have been a little richer (cars, trees, animations, pedestrians, etc).
* Recognising it was an experience focusing around jumping around buildings and parkour, I would have enjoyed a little more combative / weapon encounters.
* There is one particular part of the game when the parkour and 'movement sequence puzzle' became a little overwhelming, but not enough to not want to see it through (though I could've done with about half as much).
* No stealth. I mean this is a Pro as well, as the game is not designed to be Thief" - I feel that every other game should have develoepd the parkour elements of Mirror's Edge to this degree and not the other way around. But since it is already such a simple game

reviewText:
The City. A marvel of modern technology and science. Skyscrapers rise into the air everywhere.
While it is a beautiful sight, the City can be a dangerous place for some individuals.

In Mirrors Edge, you take the role of a Runner called Faith who's sister has been framed of a murder that she didn't commit, and you are being chased by the police, also known as 'Blues' by the Runners.

Mirrors Edge lets you preform wall-runs. death-defying leaps across buildings and vaults over objects. The graphics for Mirrors Edge are magnificient. Sometimes I just wanted to be able to stop and just soak it all in.

While the game has a very basic art style - mostly white and red with the occasional blue, orange or green - this tends to help the player focus on intense moments of action. The hud is not cluttered at all, as it only comprises of a small dot in the middle of screen, which is used for aiming weapons.

Mirrors Edge doesn't focus on combat and instead focuses on movement throughout the enviroment, which is why I would extremely recommend that you play this. 9/10

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a properly done 3d Sonic in disguise.

If you are stopping to fight enemies, you did something wrong.

In fact, if you are slowing down at all, you did something wrong.

Much like in Sonic, speed is earned in Mirror's Edge. It's the reward for doing well.

Are the levels linear? Yes. Does that make them bad? No. Does that make it so that there are no options? Heck no. If you play time trial mode, you'll quickly discover that you did the levels in the story mode all wrong- you were taking the wrong paths, timing your jumps badly, or otherwise screwing up.

The occasional platforming puzzle can sometimes be frustrating, but if you're looking for a game about dodging gunfire as you wallrun, power-slide, vault, and just flat-out RUN, you've found the right title.

Now hurry up with the damn sequel, DICE.

reviewText:
Really good game, pretty short but that just helps it to not get old.

Mind blowing textures (not so much models, but hey, those textures are amazing) on walls, pipes, and pretty much everything.

Really good fast-paced 3D platforming with a good use of enviromental movement.

The biggest flaw of the game is how it suddenly focuses in combat near the end of the game and the combat isn't particularly great, even worse, this combat sections aren't even optional, you are forced to fight many soldiers while the whole main focus of the game was running away.

There's a story but it isn't anything spectacular or mind blowing, not even surprising at all in my opinion, it's just there for the sake of making the aesthetics of the game stand out even more, which is ok but there's more that could've done to it.

Overall a good and pretty unique experience, if they ever make a sequel to this game lets hope they ditch the combat entirely and it'll be even better.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is special, because they took a very simple approach, using existing gameplay mechanics in such a way as to basically create a new genre: first-person platformer, very much inspired by parkour.

The game is pretty much flawed in some instances, perhaps by trying way too much to appeal to gamers used to first-person shooter at some points in the game.

Perhaps they didn't quite know themselves what they had in their hands when they made the game, but hopefully they can now use it to build a better sequel and in the meantime, Mirror's Edge is definitely worth a playthrough.

reviewText: Needless to say, this is one of the greatest games ever made. It's a first person parkour game. I would leave it at that but that wouldn't be very helpful. reviewText:
The City. A marvel of modern technology and science. Skyscrapers rise into the air everywhere.
While it is a beautiful sight, the City can be a dangerous place for some individuals.

In Mirrors Edge, you take the role of a Runner called Faith who's sister has been framed of a murder that she didn't commit, and you are being chased by the police, also known as 'Blues' by the Runners.

Mirrors Edge lets you preform wall-runs. death-defying leaps across buildings and vaults over objects. The graphics for Mirrors Edge are magnificient. Sometimes I just wanted to be able to stop and just soak it all in.

While the game has a very basic art style - mostly white and red with the occasional blue, orange or green - this tends to help the player focus on intense moments of action. The hud is not cluttered at all, as it only comprises of a small dot in the middle of screen, which is used for aiming weapons.

Mirrors Edge doesn't focus on combat and instead focuses on movement throughout the enviroment, which is why I would extremely recommend that you play this. 9/10

In Mirror's Edge, you can choose to either play aggressively or passively. The whole fun of the game (and the obvious core) is running around and doing parkour in possibly one of the most beautiful cities you could ever parkour in (and clean).

For a game released in 2009, it's more than what you could ask for (visually/aesthetically talking).
The clean, peaceful and safe feeling that the environment around you provides is simply amazing (which is funny seeing how sometimes you might be running for your life).

These are the movements your protagonist, Faith, uses whenever she is faced with an obstacle.\n\nThe game is an unstoppable roller coaster ride. All the movements you do you do while running. reviewText:
Freedom.
That's pretty much what this game made me feel. The platforming and running mechanics amazingly portrayed what parkour is all about. And the game gives off a definite feeling of speed and momentum as you navigate the few levels the base game has to offer. And that feeling is emphasized even further by the vibrant and colorful environments. The premise is neat but how they told the story and the characterization could have been done better. That's kinda disappointing since the player character, Faith, is pretty much a badass.

Only thing though is don't buy it on Steam. Buy the game on Origin, EA's own client, because for some absurd reason the great Time Trials DLC is not for sale here on Steam. The DLC is worth it because it's just pure running and none of the atrocious combat is present.

reviewText:
Skip to bottom for key points.

This game was straight up awesome.  Once you take the time to learn the controls and develop some rudimentary skills, the fun factor goes way up.  The most fun part of the game for me was the time trials, because it's just pure parkour all over the place.  You get to make the rooftops your own, and run/jump/climb all over your territory.  The campaign itself is quite good.  The writing isn't great, and the plot unfolds somewhat predictably, but that was never the main focus of the game.  The focus is running from the cops, or chasing other dudes, and that's where all the excitement is.  There is a ton of adrenaline value in most of the levels, and the non-chase puzzle levels are so interesting, you're still on the edge of your seat.  A lot of the enjoyment of the game comes from how good everything looks.  It's a bit unrealistic that everywhere you go is so clean and amazing looking, but that just adds to the experience, and helps to remove anything that might distract you while you run full speed past it all.  The only downside to the campaign is that once you've really hit your stride and parkour through the levels like lighting, it ends up being over rather quick, leaving you wanting more.  Then it's time to challenge yourself and run it all again, looking for quicker runs, and more efficient paths.  There's such a good selection of path options, that it really encourages you to make split second decisions, and judgement calls.  If you do get hung up, and decide to fight it out with the pursuers, there's a pretty interesting and engaging combat system.  *Spoilers*  The cops constantly try to kill you and never hesitate to open fire.  Shooting them is fun, but you don't get much ammo so if you go exterminator mode like I did, you have to plan out your attacks and work your way from enemy to enemy one at a time.  Fighting one enemy is really fun.  Fighting two gives you about a 50% survival chance but it's still doable and still fun if you pull it off.  It's understandably not fun to get mowed down from 3 or 4 different directions if you just run into the fray, and that's what happens, so you have to stay tactical.  *More SPOILERS*  The ninja dudes at the end are hard as hell to beat, but they are killable, and I figured out to beat the sh** out of those mofos, but again it involves extreme tactics.  They, like you, regenerate unless hit a lot of times in quick succession.  Get 3 good hits on them in under 10 seconds and you knock them the heck out, but that's so hard to pull off it's easier to just run away and escape them.

Just to summarize
Pros:
Fun Campaign
Fun extra modes
Awesome concepts and execution
Cool main character
Levels look cool
Parkour looks awesome and sounds awesome (the sound clips used are perfect)
Can play like a speed demon or a vengeful punisher

Cons:
Campaign is short if you speed demon the whole thing
Story is probably the least developed part of the game.
How much fun you have depends on how well you learn the system and timing.

I spent a lot of time on the levels, finding shortcuts, killing everything, and exploring, so I got a lot out of the game.  It's unique and it draws you in.  Immersive yet light on a heavy gamer's pallete.  I'd even say, it's an almost perfect game.  5/5 stars.

reviewText:
7 out of 10.  I'm giving it a thumbs-up because the free-running gameplay is an interesting mechanic, but the game has enough faults that I really only recommend it when you can find it on sale.

All in all not a very good game, even though it seems to have a pretty rabid fan base. To be fair, the graphics are very good, especially considering it's a few years old, and the developers had some innovative ideas for how to play the game. Unfortunately actually playing the game just wasn't as fun as it should have been. Mostly the game suffers from pretty bad controls coupled with unforgiving gameplay mechanics, which results in having to replay sections over and over again. Most jumps and grabs have to be precisely timed and the distance precisely judged, but many times the button presses didn't register quickly enough, and it's in general pretty difficult to judge distances, so I found myself dying dozens of times when I missed jumps by no more than an inch or two - that got frustrating really fast. The control issue also raised its ugly head in the wholly mediocre combat. Many, many times the right-mouse button counterattack failed, which got me killed more times than I could count. I eventually grew to hate the combat so much that I just pounded on the first guard I saw, took his gun, then shot everyone else just to get it over with.

The other huge frustration with the game was the fact that for such a completely linear game it was often nearly impossible to figure out where to go. There was supposed to be a hint system that highlighted your path in red, but sometimes it showed up off in the distance, sometimes not until you were right on top of the path, and sometimes not at all - I wandered around a lot because of that. Even worse was the level where the devs decided to paint everything in the building red; I don't know why, I guess maybe they just thought it was funny to frustrate us even further.

To make matters even worse (or perhaps better, as things turned out) - beyond the spotty controls, oft-failing hint system, unforgiving mechanics and mediocre combat, the game took me all of 5 hours and change to complete. I'm not necessarily opposed to short games, as long as the story is engaging and gameplay is fun - The Darkness II is a perfect example. But this game was neither engaging nor more than moderately fun, and was far too short for the money they normally charge. Luckily I got this as part of the EA Humble Bundle, so I really didn't shell anything out for it. If you can pick it up really cheap then it's fine to waste time on for a few hours, but anything more than a few bucks is probably a waste of your money.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge is a smallish morsel of amazing. Beautiful, fast-paced, exciting, and fun. The first thing you'll notice besides the lovely intro track is that this is primarily a puzzle parkour game with a little combat sprinkled in. The second is that the screenshots fail to represent just how gorgeous the game looks in motion. It has a near perfect first person movement model.

The lowest point is the predictibility of the story, but it's so well executed that you can forgive the cliches. There is an average of 6 hours of main storyline game time, so you may want to pick it up for $15 or less although there are speed runs and trials to help compensate. The parkour is more fun and dynamic than any assassin's creed and even if the levels are very linear there are multiple ways to engage each combat situation or puzzle.

Note: If you have vertigo or experience motion sickness, you definitely want to watch some videos full screen to make sure you will be able to enjoy the game without severe side-effects.

reviewText:
Did I like this game? Not at first, no. It took a while to like it. My main problem with it? Nvidia.

PhysX is awful. Its broken. It doesn't work. I spent the longest time trying to get the game to stop lagging and to stop screen-tearing. I gave up for a couple months, and eventually came back. This time I figured out what was wrong. It was PhysX. So I enabled v-sync and disabled PhysX. BAM, suddenly the game runs perfectly.

BUT when you finally get into the game, its great. The running is a bit awkward, parts of the running and stuff seem unrealistic, however on the whole, its pretty awesome. You get to run around and jump and vault and wall-run and more.

What I wish they'd fix is the combat. Its okay, I guess, but when you're trying to disarm, its a 50/50 for whether you can actually do it. Most of the time you're a split-second late or early, and the soldier kills you. You can take a few shots, but it gets to the point later in the game where you're getting killed what seems to be WAY too easily, compared to earlier in the game.

The story is great if you're paying attention. It could be a lot better, they should have revealed more about what happened to the City and how its come to this awful state its in now, but instead they set all the focus on saving Kate. Its not bad, because its still a pretty great story, but it could be better and more indepth. I figure Mirror's Edge 2 (if it ever gets released, and if DICE doesn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it up) will have all that backstory.

reviewText:
Mirror's Edge. Fast-paced action game all about momentum and using three buttons to do a million things.
The game is set in a dystopian and overly uniform city of towering skyscrapers, and the plot revolves around the murder of a close friend of the main character's family. The game is essentially get to Point A to Point B, without dying, as fast as you can. Combat is rather awkward and there isn't much of a way to learn moves except trial and error, which can prove to be extremely irratating. Graphics reflect the dystopian world in solid, vivid colors, and keep the puzzles simpler as different key objects can be easily separated by the distinct colors. Voice acting is tolerable, but not especially impressive. As previously mentioned, momentum is imperative in performinfg many of the game's not-so-realistic moves, but oddly is often lost in solving some of the intermediately difficult puzzles.
Overall, I would recommend this game.
Graphics: simple yet uniquely beautiful. Gameplay: engaging, smooth and straightforward, although some moves are difficult to figure out. Story: not exactly gripping, but good enough for a parkour game.
I would give it a confident 8/10 review.

reviewText:
My rating: 8.5 / 10

Mirror's Edge is an innovative game that will leave you looking at things a little differently.

Pros:
- Unique gameplay: Less gunning, more running leads to some fast-paced sequences.
- Fun combat system oriented around disarming enemies hand-to-hand.
- Amazing visuals. This game is gorgeous.
- Great atmosphere. The visuals and soundtrack blend well into an immersive experience.
- Strong female lead that depicts the female game character in a less sexual, more powerful way.

Cons:
- Collision glitches. Some areas will not always register your grabbing on to them, leading you to plummet to your death.
- Frequent death, can be frustrating for some.
- Sometimes combat can be glitched; disarms may not register properly.

Mirror's Edge isn't a traditional first person shooter, and that difference may be hated by some and loved by others. This game however, happens to be one of my personal favorites.

reviewText: After a long break, I finailly finished this game by switching the difficulty from normal to easy (I'm not a great player).  I really like this first person runner style, where the empahsis is moving through the levels rather than fighting opponents.  There is some combat, but at least sometimes I think you can avoid it.  I enjoyed the way you move through the city (when I wasn't falling and dying), which can give some cool views, and the story that tied things together was interesting.  There's some replay value, too, since the game includes story, race, and time trial modes.  More automatic save points in the game would have been nice, because sometimes I'd lose progress when I stopped playing.  Some parts got repetitive as I tried over and over to pass them, but that's kind of the nature of games like this.  It wasn't too frustrating (on easy) though, since after I while I could learn the general patterns and improve how I played through those parts.  Overall, I thought this was a good game, enjoyable to play, so if it sounds interesting to you, I'd recommend getting it and giving it a try.

reviewText:
Did I like this game? Not at first, no. It took a while to like it. My main problem with it? Nvidia.

PhysX is awful. Its broken. It doesn't work. I spent the longest time trying to get the game to stop lagging and to stop screen-tearing. I gave up for a couple months, and eventually came back. This time I figured out what was wrong. It was PhysX. So I enabled v-sync and disabled PhysX. BAM, suddenly the game runs perfectly.

BUT when you finally get into the game, its great. The running is a bit awkward, parts of the running and stuff seem unrealistic, however on the whole, its pretty awesome. You get to run around and jump and vault and wall-run and more.

What I wish they'd fix is the combat. Its okay, I guess, but when you're trying to disarm, its a 50/50 for whether you can actually do it. Most of the time you're a split-second late or early, and the soldier kills you. You can take a few shots, but it gets to the point later in the game where you're getting killed what seems to be WAY too easily, compared to earlier in the game.

The story is great if you're paying attention. It could be a lot better, they should have revealed more about what happened to the City and how its come to this awful state its in now, but instead they set all the focus on saving Kate. Its not bad, because its still a pretty great story, but it could be better and more indepth. I figure Mirror's Edge 2 (if it ever gets released, and if DICE doesn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it up) will have all that backstory.

Mirror's Edge is a fun, fast paced first person parkour game where you get to play as Faith, a runner(someone who act as a courier to transmit messages while evading government surveillance) as she escapes countless encounters with the government hunting her down.

It's a game where you have to parkour over objects and obstacles to reach your point of destination, occasionally fighting enemies with melee and firearms. I personally feel like the game would have been better without the shooting parts. It kind of interferes with the pace of the game imo. The graphics are beautiful, they still look good. Overall, it's a great game for anyone who wants to experience a first person parkour game.

Sound: 7.5/10 pretty good
Graphics: 8/10 good for their time, still looks good today
Gameplay: 9/10 It's innovative and good for what it does.
Characters: 5/10 nothing really interesting about them
Story: 5/10 It has a good premise but it doesn't really get better than that, pretty lacking.

Overall: 7/10 awesome game, get it if you like first person parkour

reviewText:
While I wouldn't go so far as to say this game is obscure, it certainly deserves more attention than it has received. I've never played anything quite like it. In fact, I'd like to say that Mirror's Edge is the best first-person parkour game I've ever played, but it's also the only first-person parkour game I've ever played. You know what? To hell with it. Mirror's Edge is the best first-person yada yada I've ever played, there you go. This game is something special and the experience of playing it, in spite of a few noteworthy imperfections, is awesome.

The story takes place in a large sterile looking city where The Man has established a typical sort of Orwellian society with all the usual tropes therein. Granted, this is only really explained to you through flash animation-esque cutscenes, and never really explicitly shown. There are police here, like anywhere else, and you do have to avoid and occasionally fight them, but other than that, the air of oppression that they speak of is never really conveyed through the gameplay. All I see here is a society where the cops just really don't like you running around on the roof. The plot revolves around a conspiracy and, like many conspiracies, certain details don't really add up. Expecting a tight cohesive story out of this game is probably not something you should do.

You play as Faith, a professional courier who conveys senstive items and information about the city via the art of parkour, flipping and jumping about far above the streets where the ubiquitous eye of big brother is ever watchful. Faith is an alright character. All those people who think video games are sexist might actually be okay with her. She's resourceful and athletic and determined and she also has normal sized cans, so women with average proportions don't have to be jealou- I mean, outraged at what a bunch of pigs the men who made this game are. She's also Asian, so if you're a creme colored frat boy with a weird fetish where you want to control a woman of the orient and make her do your chores and bear your children, this game is for you. I actually knew a guy in college who was like that. He constantly tried to make his American-born Vietnamese girlfriend come over and do his laundry. That relationship didn't last long. And no, he wasn't me. But I digress. Faith never does any of that, really. She's more of a sprint-up-the-wall-and-occasionally-murder-a-police-officer kind of chick.

As far as the parkour in this game is concerned, the gameplay is fluid, intuitive, and uniquely excellent in its execution. The runners of the game, runner" being the name prescribed to those of Faith's ilk

Once you get over a moderately steep learning curve, you really develop a sort of intuitive feel for how to play this game well. It's pretty cool. The only downside is you might also start to feel a little ashamed of sitting in front of a computer for hours, pretending to be an extremely athletic person by pressing a series of buttons.\n\nWhat is a little lacking in Mirror's Edge is it's combat system. reviewText:
There are two mechanics of this game that are implemented with varying amounts of success.

First: the parkour. This is the thing this game was made for. Faith runs like a dream, and there's nothing more satisfying than flying across rooftops and making those jumps that would probably break a normal person's legs. When this game is going fast, it's great.

Second: the combat. Where do I even start with this? First of all, the game encourages you to avoid combat as often as possible. After all, you're playing a fragile speedster, so when it comes to fight or flight, flight is the better option. That being said, the game often doesnt LET you avoid combat. There'll be too many people shooting at you, and even with all your running and ducking and dodging chances are you'll be gunned down in seconds. And again, you're a fragile speedster, emphasis on the fragile part. You can't take very many hits. So when running isn't an option (even though the game will remind you that you SHOULDN'T be fighting), the only other choice you have is to fight. So what's the problem with fighting? Try: most everything. The timing for disarming someone is absurdly anal (and chances are while you're doing that someone else will be shooting you in the back), the timing for striking is anal (most often they'll just block and you'll be knocked back instead), and the controls for attacking someone while moving are awkward. If you engage in hand to hand, expect to have to repeat a segment over, and over, and over.

In other words, every time combat happens, the game comes to a grinding halt. The point of the game is to be going fast and getting from place to place quickly and adeptly, but this becomes impossible when you have to slow down to fight 10 heavily armed guards that just rushed you and cut off the only escape route that doesn't end with a sickening *splat* sound. Combat completely throws off the pacing. The game tries to make the combat faster paced by causing the action to start the moment you enter a room, but this leaves no window of time for you to adjust to the surroundings. I get that part of the game is being able to react and choose routes quickly and everything, but there's only so fast a human can react before they get shot.

(And I'll add here that you could just grab a gun and use that, but there's this little notice on the pause menu that tracks if you've shot anyone yet, and though I haven't finished the game yet, I can figure it'll be important. If this doesn't bother you, go for it. The game's great.)

For all my complaining, though, I really do like this game and would recommend it, or at least the parkour parts. The combat system is poorly managed (and IMO doesn't belong in this type of game), but it isn't impossible, just incredibly frustrating. My grievances with the combat system are meant to be more of a forewarning than a dissuasion. Mechanics aside, the story, art, and voicing are fantastic, so design in that sense is solid.

TL:DR; play it, it's great, but either brace yourself for grueling combat sequences or stuff your morality and use a gun.
